_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 

Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. management, process operators, technicians, contractors plus all involved and affected employees towards safe operation. In addition, some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

This process does not meet the requirements of Program 1.  It is subject to OSHA's PSM standard.  Thus, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance. 
Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s program was updated in starting in January of 2018 in conjunction with the 5-year update and personnel change.  

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4.	The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
5.	The five-year accident history
6.	The emergency response program
7.	Planned changes to improve safety

A-1   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. is committed to complying with all the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental r

eleases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a significant release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.
State regulations require reporting when there is a significant accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment on an ongoing basis. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel, registered engineers, refrigeration experts, and certified refrigeration contractors as required review the equipment.

A-2   STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to provide cold storage and temperature cool down of harvested tree fruit crops. The refrigeration system runs almost year-round to keep cooler room temperatures for product quality.  However due to seasonal changes sometimes the system is pumped down and shut off due to no product available.

The facility is in Sutter County on a contiguous property. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the cooler refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system is a direct mechanical refrigeration system. The Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. facility was constructed in three stages.  The stages started in 1997, then in 2003 and the final building stage occurred in 2006 with minor changes made in 2016 and 2017.  

The ammonia equipment is in the machine (engine) room, outside on the

roof, and in the cold storage rooms.

A-3   HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition, the House System is separated by walls and distance. Furthermore, as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

A-3.1  SESIMIC ASSESSMENT
H&SC 25534.05(c), CCR 2755.2(d), CCR 2760.2(c)(8)

Purpose
Identifies seismic vulnerabilities that could result in an accidental release of a regulated substance and provides for required remedial action to reduce the likelihood of offsite consequences that may impact public health or the environment.

Regulations & Guidelines

As part of RMP submittal a Hazard Review must be conducted, including a seismic assessment (Walkdown) by a qualified engineer. For new facilities, prior to equipment charging, and every 5 years thereafter.  Existing facilities must perform assessments every 5 years.
The seismic assessment will be performed by an individual who is registered in California as a Civil, Structural or Mechanical Engineer with experience in seismic design and/or evaluations of stationary sources subject to CalARP.  Qualified Engineer who is knowledgeable about the applicable types of failures that may occur to structures and equipment during ground shaking or movement.  The engineer performs a methodical physical inspection or 'walkdown' of t

he stationary source.
The purpose of the walkdown is to identify vulnerabilities.  The overall objective is to maintain primary containment of regulated substances and performance criteria includes:
a.  Maintain structural integrity;
b.  Maintain position;
c.  Maintain containment of material;
d.  Function during the earthquake; and/or
e.  Function after the earthquake.

The seismic assessment as required by the California Code of Regulations Title 19 Division 2 Chapter 4.5 was performed in 2013 and all recommendations have been addressed.
  
A-4   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s Prevention Program are briefly described below:
1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers many potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements)

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements.)

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  Sacramen

to Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. certifies operators following completion of operator training and Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s confirmation of the operator's ability apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation Element)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s Management of Change Procedure. 

Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Hot Work Permit, and Pre-Startup Safety Review Elements.)

7) Verification of Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC.'s compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the prevention program has been implemented and properly documented by Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. pers

onnel.  (Addressed under Compliance Audit Element)

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under Injury and Illness Prevention Program)

Program Consolidation

The documentation requirements of these programs have been consolidated in the documenting and record filing process.   The documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program in the physical files organized by year.  The following identifies the practices and procedures for:
 
Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: 1) ammonia data such as SDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; 2) process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and 3) process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

Technical Operating Specifications and Standard Operating Procedures

The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety programs and procedures are included.

Training
All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the SDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan or action plan.

Mechanical Integrity
The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.   Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps etc.

Management of Change
The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

Pre-Startup Safety Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems and should be considered outside of the management of change proc

edure. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

Compliance Audits
To ensure that all the other areas of program are followed, the regulations require compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years.  The last two audits are kept on file.

Incident Investigation
An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated within 48-hours of an incident using a team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

Employee Participation
The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community.  As a rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the PSM program, including taking part in the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices
This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area.  Permits indicate t

he appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

Contractors and Contractor Qualifications
This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 

A-5   FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the definition of a reportable accident according the program regulations.

A-6   EMERGENCY ACTION PROGRAM

This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Action Plan developed for Sacramento Valley Walnut Growers Capital Group LLC. for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel shall coordinate with responding outside agencies such as fire and Sutter County Environmental Health. The facilities emergency action plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility can coordinate with outside parties through drills and attendance at Ammonia Safety Days. Facility personnel will exchange data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency.  In addition, Fire Department personnel should tour the facility frequently to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responders and company personnel.  All areas (zones) can be brought under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel/contract

ors are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  

The emergency action plan for all releases is to gain access to the shutdown valves and controls for the system with the release.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches and controls are identified at the facility.  

On-site personnel do not enter an atmosphere above the Cal/OSHA IDLH which is 300 ppm for ammonia.  Incidental responders are trained to retreat at 25 ppm and don respirators for re-entry.  Facility personnel will assist outside agencies in a plant advisory role during larger releases or atmospheres exceeding the IDLH unless the release can be controlled defensively to reduce the level to less than the IDLH. All personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for.
